paper_metadata.title: Bottom-up wheat seed technology transfer in northwest Bangladesh

program_information.program_name: Bottom-up wheat seed technology transfer program

component_b_assets.assets_evidence_citation: The bottom-up wheat seed dissemination system involved the creation of an enabling environment which allowed poor and ultra-poor farmers to store and sell selected seed of recently-released wheat varieties that they produced in 20 decimal (0.08 ha) plots.

study_characteristics.outcomes_evidence_citation: farmers can obtain a 52% increase in wheat grain yield and extra income by switching from the old Kanchan variety to the newer, heat and disease-tolerant Shatabdi variety
study_characteristics.design_evidence_citation: This paper reports on a 'bottom-up' system of wheat seed technology transfer that was piloted in northwest Bangladesh with 45 mainly marginal (food insecure) farming families during the 2004-2005 wheat season, then scaled out to a further 545 mainly marginal, farming families during the 2006-2007 season

bonus_information.cost_mentions: Seed sales and profit data reported
bonus_information.cost_evidence_citation: This seed was sold at Tk25-30/kg and realised profits averaging Tk3,002 (â‚¬38.49; exchange rate was 78:1 in October 2005) per household

evidence_citations.program_name_citation: This paper reports on a 'bottom-up' system of wheat seed technology transfer that was piloted in northwest Bangladesh
evidence_citations.country_citation: This paper reports on a 'bottom-up' system of wheat seed technology transfer that was piloted in northwest Bangladesh
evidence_citations.target_population_citation: piloted in northwest Bangladesh with 45 mainly marginal (food insecure) farming families
